intro: Tricholepidium pteropodum, commonly known as the white-flowered false indigo, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Fabaceae family, characterized by its compound leaves and pod-like fruits. The plant features showy, white to pale blue flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland or wetland habitats. Its ornamental value makes it a popular choice for gardeners seeking native plants with aesthetic appeal.
